CHIT FUND COMPANIES
(Winding up)


    1. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Law whether he will make a statement on the affairs of the chit fund companies which were ordered to be wound up with particular reference to the affairs of the Gemini Chit Fund and say how much has been realised in the winding up

Column: 1130

to date and how much has been paid out to the contributors to the various funds.

     The Minister for Law (Mr E.W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Chit Funds Act came into operation on 14th January, 1972. Since then, a total of 26 chit fund companies have been ordered by the Court to be wound up mainly upon the application of the Minister for Finance. The Official Receiver was appointed liquidator of 22 companies, and the remaining four were administered by private liquidators. Subsequently, however, the liquidators of

Column: 1131

these four companies made applications to Court to transfer the liquidation to the Official Receiver.

    The main assets of these companies are monies owing by subscribers who had successfully bid in the chit fund groups before the companies were wound up. The collection of these debts takes time; a debtor paying under a Court instalment order may take several years before he finally pays up the debt.

    However, in order to assist the creditor-subscribers, interim dividends are declared as and when there are sufficient funds to do so. To-date the subscribers of nine chit fund companies have received a 100% dividend exceeding $2,375,000. Interim dividends totalling about $22,237,000 have been paid to the subscribers of the remaining 17 chit fund companies.

    Particulars of these companies and other details are given in two Tables (Cols. 1223 - 1224) which are with the Clerk of the House, (marked Appendices I and II).

DEFERMENT/EXEMPTION FROM NATIONAL SERVICE
(Particulars)


    2. Mr Lim Boon Heng asked the Minister of Defence how many applications for deferment of and exemption from national service were received in 1981 and how many of these applications were granted and on what grounds.

     The Minister of State of Defence (Dr Yeo Ning Hong) (for the Minister of Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, persons liable for national service, but assessed by Mindef to be medically unfit, are given exemption from all forms of national service. In 1981, 1,425 registrants (meaning those who have registered for national service but have not been enlisted) were exempted. In the same year, of those who have been enlisted,

Column: 1132

3,358 servicemen (including reservists) were exempted from further national service on medical grounds.

    Applications for exemption on medical grounds are granted only if the person is certified by a Mindef Medical Board, consisting of three doctors, to be permanently unfit for national service. However, for those who possess GCE 'A' level qualifications, even if they are medically unfit, they will still be enlisted and will be posted to sedentary jobs instead of undergoing military training. This is to ensure that those who are medically unfit do not have an advantage over those who are fit in respect of entering the university. Many such cases help out in Government Ministries. They work under the supervision of experienced staff.

    Each application for exemption on grounds other than medical grounds is examined by an Advisory Board consisting of prominent citizens and senior SAF officers. Most applications are made on grounds of financial hardship and every case is thoroughly investigated before the full facts are submitted to the Advisory Board. When the Board finds that a case merits special consideration, it will decide either (i) that financial assistance be provided during the full-time national service period, or (ii) that deferment of enlistment for full-time national service be granted, or (iii) that the applicant be permitted enlistment into the Vigilante Corps instead of the SAF, Police, or Fire Brigade.

    In 1981, a total of 699 applications on grounds of financial hardship were received. Of these, 537 cases were rejected, 116 were offered financial assistance of up to $300 per month during their full-time national service; 21 had their enlistment deferred, and the remaining 24 were enlisted into the Vigilante Corps.

    In addition to the deferment of enlistment for full-time national service granted to a few hardship cases, there are various deferment schemes for the following groups of registrants:

    (a) Full-time students in Government or Government-aided schools, and other recognized educational institutions.

Column: 1133



    (b) Personnel in the essential uniformed services.

    (c) Trainees in approved technical and vocational apprenticeship training schemes, and

    (d) those who are temporarily medically unfit for national service.

    For those who have performed their national service full-time, there is still the question of deferment from in-camp training. Reservists are now being informed six to 12 months in advance of the date of their next in-camp training. They can thus make the appropriate arrangements well ahead of time. Therefore, deferment from in-camp training is allowed only after Mindef is convinced that the circumstances are clearly beyond the control of the reservist and/or his employer. In 1981, only 5% of those called up for in-camp training were given deferment on their application. As the message gets through that reservists are given six to 12 months' prior notice for their in-camp training, there will be little ground to seek deferment. Mindef will therefore be tightening and will be stricter in granting further deferments for in-camp training.

    By far the greatest proportion of applications for deferment of in-camp training comes from reservists who are officers and NCOs. This is because, generally, they hold more responsible positions in their civilian employment. Unfortunately, granting deferment to such reservists will also cause the greatest upset to the military units in which they serve. For example, if a Company Commander is deferred from in-camp training, all the soldiers who train under him in the Company will suffer as he and his men who have been used to his command will not be able to train together for that one year. This represents obviously a great loss. Reservists and their employers are, therefore, urged to assist the SAF, and to appreciate the situation in which we operate, and to extend to us their fullest cooperation and support in our arrangements for in-camp training.

NOISE NUISANCE BY RSAF AIRCRAFT AT PAYA LEBAR


    3. Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe asked the Minister of Defence if he is aware of the noise pollution caused by aircraft of the Republic of Singapore Air Force and what measures are being taken to minimise the inconvenience to residents in the vicinity of the Paya Lebar Airport.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong (for the Minister of Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Ministry of Defence has been conscious of the problems of aircraft noise since it acquired jet trainers for the Air Force in the early Seventies. In the case of Paya Lebar Airport, the problem was recognized long before our RSAF started operations in July last year. The RSAF has implemented

Column: 1135

various measures to minimize the noise problem and these measures include:

    (a) operating aircraft at minimum power when flying over densely populated areas;

    (b) conducting flights whenever possible at heights above 1,500 feet;

    (c) avoiding built-up areas where possible, and

    (d) keeping night flying to the minimum and, as far as possible, not beyond 11.00 p.m.

    Mindef is also looking for other means of reducing noise created by aircraft engine ground runs by installing noise suppression devices. These measures to reduce aircraft noise will be closely monitored and will be improved wherever possible.

    Owing to land limitations in Singapore, residential areas and airports are located in close proximity. It is, therefore, inevitable that aircraft noise will affect all Singaporeans to a greater or lesser extent. Mindef asks that residents around Paya Lebar Airport give us their understanding and support, knowing the situation as it is in Singapore. In its own very special way, that sound is the audible sign of our security and stability.

     The Minister of State for National Development (Mr Lee Yock Suan) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Housing and Develop

ment Board will be constructing an overhead bridge across Jalan Toa Payoh at Rajah Court. Work will commence in October 1982 and end in March 1983.

    The Public Works Department is fully aware of the need to provide pedestrian crossing facilities along Balestier Road. There are five sets of traffic lights with green/red man signals and two push-button pedestrian crossing lights along Balestier Road between Thomson Road and Serangoon Road. The PWD will be constructing a pedestrian overhead bridge across Balestier Road at the McNair Road junction to replace the existing push-button pedestrian crossing lights. This will further enhance the safety of pedestrians and improve traffic flow. Work will commence in May 1982 and end in October 1982.

    A second pedestrian overhead bridge is also planned to be constructed near the junction of Mandalay Road/Balestier Road. Work is expected to start in August 1982 and be completed by the end of the year.

DEVELOPMENT CHARGE


    5. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development whether he is aware of complaints that the development charge is too high and whether he will take steps to reduce it.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am aware of the complaints made by developers that the development charge is too high. However, I believe that this is because they are not very clear on how development charge is arrived at or how their interests are protected in the system of levying development charge.

    Development charge is intended to cream off part of the windfall gains from increases in land values arising from approvals to develop land not in conformity with the Master Plan. It is based on 70% of the increase in land value as determined on a case-by-case basis by the Chief Valuer. This system is fair to all, since land value varies widely from locality to locality and at different points in time. Development charges are as high or as

Column: 1137

low as property prices at the time of approval of the development project. In the event that developers dispute the quantum of development charge, there is an avenue of appeal to the Minister.

    The present procedure for the determination of development charge ensures that development is not discouraged. Development charge is determined at the date of the grant of in-principle approval and remains valid for a period of 12 months or until written permission is issued, whichever is earlier. This protects the developer in both a rising as well as a failing property market. In a rising market, with development charge determined on the date of in-principle approval, the developer is protected for up to one year from having to pay higher development charges from rising land values. In a property downturn, the developer can get a new determination of development charge after the expiry of 12 months to benefit from failing land values. Alternatively, he can abort his original planning application before the 12-month period and resubmit for a new in-principle approval upon which development charge will be determined.

    There are no plans to review the present system of development charges since this is a fair system and reflects the current values of the property market.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Minister of State about an appeal to the Minister? Who is the Minister advised by when he sits on this appeal? Does he take an opinion from outside valuers, or is he advised by the Government Valuer who made the valuation in the first instance?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: The appeal is considered by three parties. The developer himself is present at the appeal. Then there is he Government Valuer and there is the Valuation Appeals Inspector appointed by the Minister. On the basis of the evidence provided by both the developer and the valuer, the independent Inspector will submit a report to the Minister for National Development who will decide on the case.

     The Minister for the Environment (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Mr Speaker, before the House adjourned yesterday, I was recounting to the Member for Kebun Baru the progress of cleaning up the Singapore and Kallang Rivers, One notable success in the cleaning up efforts is the reappearance of prawns and crabs in the rivers and the absence of foul stench from the Rochor Canal.

    Sir, we must remove sources of pollution in order to clean up the rivers and water catchments. Some sources of pollution, such as waste water from households, can be controlled by connecting the premises to sewers. Other sources which cannot be controlled, such as pig farms, street hawkers and squatter pockets, will have to be resettled.

    The Ministry of the Environment undertook a survey in 1977 to identify all the sources of pollution affecting our rivers and water catchments. A programme was then drawn up to coordinate the efforts of other Ministries to remove the sources of pollution. The main sources of pollution are from pigs and ducks, trade and backyard industries, rundown urban areas, squatter pockets, street hawkers and riverine activities.

    Under the cleaning up programme, premises have been connected to sawers thereby reducing the number of premises served by nightsoil buckets and over-hanging latrines. Street hawkers have

Column: 1139

been resited into proper markets and food centres which are provided with anti-pollution facilities. The Ministry is also extending refuse removal service to another 581 premises by December 1981. Except for one, all the pig farms in the Kallang River catchment have been resited or encouraged to change trade. Action is being taken to phase out the last pig farm in the catchment. The progress is in the Annex (Cols. 1225 - 1228) which the Clerk of Parliament will distribute to Members.
Annex - PROGRESS OF CLEANING UP PROGRAMME (Cols. 1225 - 1228)


    Mr Speaker, Sir, the installation of the R2 sewerage system to provide modern sanitation for individual rural premises in Kranji, Pandan, Jurong and western catchments is progressing well. This is evident in Kampong Chantek, Lorong Temechut and Lorong Kebasi areas where they are now much cleaner. A similar programme for the new catchments of Sungei Seletar and Bedok has just started and is targetted for completion in 1984.

    In the run-down urban areas, the redevelopment programme is being carried out in phases. The areas in Kim Seng Road, Jalan Besar, Sungei Road, Beach Road and Jalan Sultan have already been or are being redeveloped into residential and commercial centres with built-in anti-pollution facilities. However, the progress of the redevelopment of run-down urban areas is expected to slow down owing to difficulties in clearance and resettlement. Meanwhile, all premises in urban areas which are not due for clearance within one year will be required to connect to public sewers.

    The Port of Singapore Authority is building a wharf and other ancillary facilities at Pasir Panjang for the lighters which now operate along the Singapore River, Kallang Basin and Telok Ayer Basin. These projects are likely to be completed in 1983 or 1984 when the lighters will be relocated.

    When the sources of pollution have been removed by 1984, there will be a further programme to dredge the rivers and improve the river banks. My Ministry

Column: 1140

is working closely with the Urban Redevelopment Authority and the PSA on how to improve the appearance of the Singapore River and its immediate environment. For the future, Singapore River will be landscaped with parks and footpaths along the banks. Our citizens will be able to fish in the river in pleasant and relaxing surroundings.

     Mr Ong Pang Boon: Sir, I will reply to the Member for Punggol and the Member for Kebun Baru and the rest together.

    Sir, the provision under this subhead is for subsidizing the construction of R2 sewerage system in Kranji, Pandan, Seletar, Jurong and the western water catchment areas. The R2 is a cheap rural sanitation system suitable for dwellings in rural areas where sewers are not available. The provision of R2 sewerage system in these water catchment areas will also reduce pollution of our reservoirs. A total of 6,300 R2 systems have already been constructed both inside and outside catchment areas. Another 2,700 R2 systems will be constructed by early 1983. The provision of $900,000 for FY 82 will be sufficient for constructing all the R2 systems in catchment areas.

    Sir, rural premises in non-water catchments are also required to install the R2 system not only to prevent water pollution but also to improve public health by phasing out the nightsoil buckets. The use of nightsoil buckets increases the hazards of infectious diseases. The dwindling workforce of nightsoil workmen will soon not be able to remove all the nightsoil buckets daily. Besides, there have been no new entrants into this occupation. We have therefore no choice but to phase out all the nightsoil buckets in Singapore by 1984. Thus in rural areas where houses are due for clearance within two years, we will not require the occupiers to install the R2 system.

    Several Members have mentioned the financial hardship that will befall the householders who have been served with notice to install the R2 system. Mr Speaker, Sir, the average cost of constructing the R2 system is about $1,200 to $1,300. This, of course, does not include the cost of installing the sanitary appliances which amount to another $300 to $700, depending on the quality. But for those who face financial hardship, the Government has a scheme to assist them in constructing the R2 system. Families whose combined income is less than $800

per month may take advantage of this scheme by applying to the Sewerage Department. The Sewerage Department will then carry out the work on their behalf and the families can pay back the cost in instalments over a period of five years.
